importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the LEAP trial results were published, leading to new medical guidelines recommending early introduction of peanuts to infants.
When expanded guidelines for early allergen introduction were issued, leading to increased adoption and a further decline in peanut allergy rates.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The decade-long period during which early peanut introduction guidelines have been implemented and shown to significantly reduce peanut allergy incidence in the U.S.

keyTakeAways: Early introduction of peanut products to infants—starting as early as 4 months—has led to a more than 27% decline in peanut allergies among children aged 0 to 3, and over 40% decline after expanded recommendations in 2017.
About 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015, following the updated medical guidance.
The LEAP (Learning Early About Peanut Allergy) trial, led by Gideon Lack at King’s College London, demonstrated that early exposure to peanuts reduces future allergy risk by more than 80%.
Despite initial resistance due to confusion and uncertainty, adoption of the guidelines has increased, with new research showing measurable public health impacts.

Current guidance (updated in 2021) recommends introducing allergenic foods like peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt, and tree nut butters between 4 and 6 months of age, without prior screening.
Experts such as Dr. David Hill of Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia and Tiffany Leon, a registered dietitian and FARE director, support early allergen introduction based on scientific evidence.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after a landmark study by Gideon Lack at King’s College London demonstrated that early introduction of peanuts to infants could prevent life-threatening food allergies, new research shows that this public health intervention has made a measurable impact. Since the 2015 LEAP trial, guidelines recommending early peanut exposure have been adopted, resulting in a 27% to 40% decline in peanut allergy rates among young children. Data from pediatric practices show that about 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015, with the most significant decline occurring after expanded guidance in 2017. Despite initial resistance due to confusion, the practice has gained traction, supported by evidence from studies and experts such as Dr. David Hill and FARE. The current recommendation is to introduce allergenic foods like peanut butter, soy-based yogurt, and tree nut butters between 4 and 6 months of age, without prior screening. This shift represents a major advance in preventive medicine and public health, reducing the incidence of one of the most common and dangerous childhood allergies.
title: New Research Shows Early Peanut Introduction Has Reduced Allergy Rates in U.S. Children
